comments.content: Please disregard. Looped square does have a link blocked but it is between the access switches, not uplinks. Correct answers are looped square and inverted U.

discussion.content: if there are two possible answers then they shoud be loop-free, as question demands all links active. Looped square has links blocked by STP

The question said (not include in this site) choose 2 answers 
so both of you are correct loop square and inverted U.

the reason why I believe it is correct as D is because it doesn't have a single point of failure
looped square
Support VLAN extension and Layer 2
adjacency across access layer switches
• Resiliency achieved with dual
homing (STP controlled)
• Offer quick convergence with
802.W/S STP standards
• In case of an access to distribution link failure
or a distribution switch failure, the second
access switch will carry all the traffic load
of both access switches
• 50 percent of access layer traffic might
cross the inter-distribution switch link
to reach the active FHRP

Loop Free Inverted U
• Support VLAN extension and Layer 2
adjacency across access layer switches
• No STP blocking; all uplinks are active
• If access switch uplink fails or one distribution
switch fails, the devices connected to that access
switch will be isolated (single point of failure)
Umm - think looped square is correct as well.

questions.question_text: A network engineer is designing an access layer that requires all uplinks to be active. Furthermore, VLANs must span across the entire switch block. What design fulfills this requirement?
In what situation must spanning-tree be implemented?

choices.C: when trunks need to extend multiple VLANs across access switches
choices.B: when a VLAN spans access layer switches to support business applications
choices.A: when first hop redundancy protocol exists with redundant Layer 2 links between distribution switches
choices.D: when it is necessary to speed up network convergence in case of link failure

discussion.content: The answer is A. Makes more sense with redundant L2 links....

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Based on the configuration, why are routers R1 and R2 not exchanging OSPF routes?

discussion.content: From an OSPF design point of view, the backbone area is extremely important. Therefore, it is always recommended to design area 0 to be as small and stable as possible.

choices.D: OSPF is not enabled on the interfaces.
choices.A: The OSPF process numbers are different.
choices.B: There is no backbone area configured.

discussion.content:
Web Security Appliance 
Cloud Web Security
A and B

questions.question_text: Which two technologies provide web and URL filtering and mitigate zero-day malware? (Choose two.)
Which statement about the ToR design model is true?

discussion.content: B could be an answer but makes no sense with FEX devices. They are managed by the distribution host in that scenario.

choices.D: It can connect servers that are located in separate racks.
choices.A: It can shorten cable runs and simplify rack connectivity.
choices.B: Each ToR switch must be individually managed.
choices.C: Multiple ToR switches can be interconnected to provide a loop-free spanning-tree infrastructure.
